text: <@U01JP5NAGKT> can you have someone review it for you before sending? is it possible you're working so much on them that you're just critical of the result no matter what? sounds like you're being really hard on yourself.

elements.text: can you have someone review it for you before sending? is it possible you're working so much on them that you're just critical of the result no matter what? sounds like you're being really hard on yourself.

text: <@U01JP5NAGKT> You’re not alone! Writing cover letters is a completely different skill set than other types of writing. I’ve found one thing that makes it easier is to ignore 99 percent of the “advice” out there and just write in my voice. Every email I write, every client interaction I have, every time I talk to my team—I will be using my voice. I will never be using that up-sell, inauthentic voice advice sites tell you to use. If a company doesn’t like it, then they’re not a good match because your voice is what they’re going to get when you’re on the job. Take the advice about what to include (problems you’ve solved, how you can solve problems at the company you want to work for, etc.), but do it in your voice. Record yourself talking about your problem solving and team building and then translate that into a cover letter. At the very least, you will hate the cover letter less :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Best advice I ever got on this was from a teacher in my last year of college:
• Identify the 3-5 most important skills in the JD
• list them out in succinct bullet points
• speak _directly_ to your experience with those things
As someone who has now reviewed hundreds of cover letters I understand how valuable this is! It takes time to tease out how relevant a person's skills are to the role based on resume alone! make it easy for the hiring manager by being like: here's what you want, here's what I have.

So few people do this and it is truly a gift when I find someone using this format.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

So few people do this and it is truly a gift when I find someone using this format.

text: These are such great suggestions, thank you! <@U01EJ7VE9FD> - You’ve definitely hit the nail on the head! I am definitely my own worst critic (aren’t we all?), and I’ve overthought my cover letters to the point of pretty much thinking everything is terrible.

elements.text: These are such great suggestions, thank you!
- You’ve definitely hit the nail on the head! I am definitely my own worst critic (aren’t we all?), and I’ve overthought my cover letters to the point of pretty much thinking everything is terrible.

text:
<@U01BLESEU1E> - Definitely agree about ‘my own voice’ - I hate sounding fake in any way - maybe one of the reasons they never sound good to me is because they’re not truly in my own voice.

<@UJG12DM1V> - I love the suggestion on the bullet points, using the JD - I think I may have done this before, but I tended toward paragraphs rather than bullets. Why use 3 words when 8 sound better! :see_no_evil:

I think the combined advice here might be what I need to get over my “writers block”. Thank you all so much!

I think the combined advice here might be what I need to get over my “writers block”. Thank you all so much!

text:
Hi everyone! I come from a museum background and want to transition to content strategy because I love learning about people, understanding their needs and using content to guide them to solutions. I'm a naturally curious, organized and empathetic problem solver who is actively looking to use my skills to organize and create content that enhances the user experience and drives brand awareness.

I would love to connect with anyone for a brief chat about their experience in becoming a content strategist-especially if you came from a non-tech background.

Also, please feel free to connect with me on <https://www.linkedin.com/in/brienne-wong/|Linkedin>. I'm happy to support people's journeys as best I can!

I would love to connect with anyone for a brief chat about their experience in becoming a content strategist-especially if you came from a non-tech background.

Also, please feel free to connect with me on
Linkedin
. I'm happy to support people's journeys as best I can!

text: Happy to chat, though I sort of organically became a content strategist vs actively aiming to achieve that title. I come from a marketing / digital advertising background with a strength in writing... so I was doing "content strategy" before that was a coined term. (We'd've maybe called it a digital communications strategy or whatever else was hype ~5-7 years ago.)

text: Hi Brienne! My background is in translation, so a bit of a change there. Would love to chat with you.

elements.text: Hi Brienne! My background is in translation, so a bit of a change there. Would love to chat with you.

text: Hi!! I am not really a content strategist BUT have worked adjacent to a couple of museum professionals. Just wanna say you can explicitly reframe a lot of that experience in terms of content strategy, if you don't already. I use that trick all the time. Then people focus on your existing skills because it's less I _can_ do this, and more _I've already done it_ ...at least sort of
